review: When the Chromecast first came out, I looked again into the whole streaming devices, and ended buying a Roku. Before Christmas, Google released a number of additional apps for the Chromecast and I bought one on top the the Roku I already have.Long story short, I end up using the Chromecast much more than the Roku. Both do basically do the same thing but the Chromecast is much easier to use.

review: I ordered my first Chromecast as soon as I heard about it, and I have since purchased 6 more (1 for another TV and 5 gifts). Not only is it fun and useful enough to recommend to friends, it's also inexpensive enough to give as a simple gift. I can't really speak to its ease of use since I'm somewhat techie. That said, I have had no problems using it from my Android tablet and phone as well as my Macbook Air and PC running Windows 7. Some people have pointed out that an Apple TV or next-gen game console offer the same functionality, but you're unlikely to buy such a device for every TV in the house. The Chromecast is inexpensive and simple enough that you can put one on all your televisions not hooked up to media servers and still access everything everywhere!
author: JCo

review: Box says "Send video or anything on the web to your TV from your smartphone, tablet or laptop"  Unfortunately "anything" doesn't include video from websites like CBS.com  full episodes of TV shows, or any other streaming video you can find by searching the internet.  At least I have not been able to figure out how to do it.  All the on-line research says it only supports YouTube and then some other video applications that you end up having to pay for.  Therefore, I feel it is a bait & switch and is not as advertised. I can't send MOST of what I want to watch from the web to my TV using this device.  :-(
